class FontManager

Detailed Description

This class represents an instance of a font that can draw immediately to the screen, or into a mesh.

The glyphs used by the standard Font class are guaranteed only to exist for one frame. If you are using the drawIntoMesh methods and want the glyphs to stay around for as long as your mesh is in use, then use the CachedFont class instead.

The font class includes all font metrics, and can be drawn proportionally or fixed. The only states a Font has is scale, and colour. ( and perhaps indirectly a font metrics cache )

void Font::drawIntoMesh ( VectorNoDestructor< Moo::VertexXYZDUV2 > &  mesh,
const std::wstring &  str,
float  clipX,
float  clipY,
float  w,
float  h,
float *  retW = NULL,
float *  retH = NULL,
bool  multiline = false,
bool  colourFormatting = false 
) [virtual]

This method draws the given string into a mesh.

The mesh contains vertices in clip coordinates, and is anchored at the top left. The required dimensions are passed in, and the string is resized to exactly fit within the area.

Parameters:
mesh The mesh to draw into.
str The string to draw.
clipX The starting X coordinate in clip space.
clipY The starting Y coordinate in clip space.
w The desired width.
h The desired height.
retW The width being used is returned in this variable (if provided).
retH The height being used is returned in this variable (if provided).

float Font::drawIntoMesh ( VectorNoDestructor< Moo::VertexXYZDUV2 > &  mesh,
const std::wstring &  str,
float  clipX = 0.f,
float  clipY = 0.f,
float *  retW = NULL,
float *  retH = NULL,
bool  multiline = false,
bool  colourFormatting = false 
) [virtual]

This method draws the given string into a mesh.

The mesh contains vertices in clip coordinates, and is anchored at the top left.

Note the text is added to the mesh, so make sure you clear the mesh first, if that is what you require.

Parameters:
mesh The mesh to draw into.
str The string to draw.
clipX The starting X coordinate in clip space.
clipY The starting Y coordinate in clip space.
retW The final X position (NOT width).
retH The height of the string.
Returns:
float The width of the string.

int Font::drawString ( std::wstring  wstr,
int  x,
int  y,
int  w,
int  h,
int  minHyphenWidth = 0,
const std::wstring &  wordBreak = L" ",
const std::wstring &  punctuation = L",<.>/?;:'\"[{]}\\|`~!@#$%^&*()-_=+" 
) [virtual]

This method draws the string directly onto the screen with width and height limit, using the current material settings.

Parameters:
wstr The string to draw.
x The x coordinate, in pixels.
y The y coordinate, in pixels.
w The max width, in pixels.
h The max height, in pixels.
minHyphenWidth If width is smaller than it, we will break the next word by hyphen.
wordBreak Glyphs act as word breaks.
punctuation Glyphs act as word punctuations.
Returns:
int The height of the real string output in pixels

float Font::makeCharacter ( Moo::VertexXYZDUV2 *  vert,
wchar_t  c,
const Vector2 &  pos 
) [protected, virtual]

This method puts a character into the vertex mesh.

Six vertices will be made, so make sure that there is room enough. Vertices are generated ready for render with drawPrimitiveUP.

Parameters:
vert Pointer to six vertices to be filled.
c The character to draw into the vertex array.
pos The clip position to make the character at.
Returns:
width The width of the character, in clip coordinates This includes the effects margin.
